4.96.text:
Hi, I'm Dr. Joe Nichols
from Seattle, Washington.

11.56.text:
The goals of this program
are to: describe the role

14.26.text:
of documentation and coding
in medical care;

17.50.text:
additionally, we want
to characterize the type

19.89.text:
of information that should be
documented with ICD-10,

24.36.text:
with the same documentation
that is needed

29.92.text:
We're going to try
to address some questions

34.00.text:
in the course
of this presentation:

35.86.text:
Why are clinical documentation
and good coding important?

39.23.text:
How can we make
ICD-10 transition easier

42.26.text:
to both the clinician
and the coder?

44.83.text:
What type of documentation
is needed

53.79.text:
in terms of ICD-10,
in this transition?

58.66.text:
what needs to be documented
and identify that?

61.76.text:
And why is coding
for specificity

66.63.text:
of the patient
health condition important?

69.20.text:
How can the provider make sure
that documentation quality

72.20.text:
and coding quality
is achieved and maintained?

77.00.text:
So why is it important?
Well, for one thing,

79.46.text:
it supports proper payment
and reduces denials.

82.83.text:
It ensures accurate measures
of quality and efficiency;

89.50.text:
it captures the level
of risk and severity;

99.53.text:
and it enhances communication
with hospitals, other providers.

102.96.text:
The most important reason
for good documentation is

108.96.text:
If we look historically
at how we've used these codes,

112.36.text:
one of the things that stands
out is that we've only used

114.83.text:
a very small percentage
of the codes, historically.

117.36.text:
This was based off of a study
that I did a couple of years ago

120.92.text:
that looked at 3 years of data,
about a million lives,

124.36.text:
for a payer that covered
all lines of business

128.07.text:
and, in this study, 72.5%
of all the charges

133.20.text:
were coded with 5%
of the codes,

135.69.text:
so we've traditionally only used
a very small percentage

138.73.text:
of the codes for a very large
percentage of the business.

141.76.text:
Now, this is not necessarily
a good thing, because,

144.20.text:
as we look at some
of those codes,

145.63.text:
we find that many of them
are extremely vague

148.13.text:
and it's very difficult to tell
what actually was going on

150.92.text:
with the patient
because they tend to be

155.26.text:
As a matter fact,
in looking at the study,

157.17.text:
54% of all the codes
over those 3 years

160.23.text:
were either unspecified, other,
or pure symptom-type codes, so,

164.56.text:
moving forward, in ICD-10, we
hope to get a lot better data.

168.36.text:
We have to change,
historically, what we've done,

170.17.text:
in terms of
our coding patterns,

171.89.text:
and all this goes back
to basic clinical documentation.

175.36.text:
We can't code
what isn't documented.

178.07.text:
If we look at the
transition from ICD-9,

180.20.text:
we also see that there
are substantial differences

185.53.text:
The area of musculoskeletal care
is highly impacted by ICD-10:

189.56.text:
we have a lot more codes, and
there's a good reason for that.

196.17.text:
to almost 17,000 codes
for fractures in ICD-10.

203.69.text:
in terms of the number of codes,
but, if you look

208.89.text:
for almost every code,
there's a separate code

214.79.text:
So if you look
at the number of codes,

216.46.text:
we actually should have
3 times as many codes.

219.07.text:
We actually only have
twice as many codes,

221.33.text:
which suggests that,
if we factor out the conditions

227.69.text:
we actually have
less codes, overall.

231.17.text:
In looking at things
like diabetes,

232.83.text:
we have more codes
because we've combined many

234.96.text:
of the different complications
of diabetes with the code,

237.96.text:
so we now have
a lot of codes

239.66.text:
with all of the
complications attached.

242.17.text:
In some areas,
the codes have gone down.

247.59.text:
the number of codes
has decreased.

249.69.text:
Hypertensive disease:
half the number of codes.

251.86.text:
End-stage renal disease:
half the number of codes.

254.26.text:
So the impact, in terms
of just the number of codes,

257.03.text:
is highly variable, depending on
the specific type of condition,

260.46.text:
and every condition
is somewhat different,

262.89.text: as it has been in ICD-9.

266.23.text:
Just to look at why
we have so many codes,

268.69.text:
and particularly looking
at fracture codes,

270.73.text:
because that seems to be
the greatest number of codes;

273.30.text:
almost 25%
of all the ICD-10 codes

278.23.text:
And, if we look
in the tabular index,

280.00.text:
we'll see a section called
fracture of the femur,

282.33.text:
fracture of one bone,
for which there's 2,466 codes.

288.59.text:
2,466 ways to break the femur;
it's really because

292.63.text:
we have a lot of
different characteristics

294.83.text:
of all of these
different fractures

296.36.text:
where we describe:
is this the initial encounter,

298.53.text:
is it the subsequent encounter,
is it normal healing,

304.03.text:
is it an open fracture and,
if so, what type?

308.03.text:
And so we have a lot
of characteristics

309.79.text:
about each fracture and,
as we add those characteristics,

314.00.text:
we end up
with a lot more codes

315.63.text:
because we end up
multiplying them.

317.59.text:
If you think about CPT
and having a modifier,

320.76.text:
if we had a different code
for right and left in CPT,

324.83.text:
we'd have twice
as many codes

326.17.text:
for those things that
represent right and left,

328.20.text:
but, instead,
we have a modifier,

331.26.text:
so it's the structure
and the nature of the codes

332.59.text:
that cause us to have
so many codes.

340.96.text: We do have a lot of ability

343.10.text:
to identify key parameters
of severity and risk in ICD-10

348.66.text:
that we couldn't quite
identify previously in ICD-9:

352.69.text:
more specific things about
comorbidities, manifestations,

360.96.text:
and all of these things
have a huge impact,

363.33.text:
in terms of the risk
and severity

367.86.text:
For example,
if we have a patient

369.69.text:
who has a fracture
of the right hip,

371.59.text:
if they have
a subcapital fracture,

374.66.text:
the mortality and morbidity
is substantially reduced

377.36.text:
because you can do
the operation quite quickly

379.89.text:
and you can get the patient
up the next day.

381.50.text:
Those are the two factors
that have the most impact,

384.59.text:
in terms of mortality
and morbidity,

389.86.text:
it's a bit more complex
and it's a bit slower,

391.86.text:
in terms of getting
patients up;

393.36.text:
and, for a subtrochanteric
fracture, we now have

395.86.text:
a very unstable-type fracture,
where the operation

398.79.text:
is quite lengthy
and it takes a long time

400.96.text:
and a great deal of care,
in terms of getting patients up.

404.43.text:
Well, those fractures are
3 inches from each other,

406.59.text:
but the morbidity and mortality
from those fractures

410.50.text:
so very small differences in
anatomy or other characteristics

414.17.text:
make a huge difference,
in terms of the risk

416.79.text:
and complexity and severity
of these conditions.

420.40.text:
Now, there's nothing new
about clinical documentation.

422.07.text:
I pulled up a record from
the Internet, back from 1889,

425.96.text:
and this was the evaluation
of a patient

428.26.text:
who got shot in the thigh from
a musket during the Civil War

432.13.text:
and was complaining that they
had rheumatism because of this

435.73.text:
and wanted an increase
in the disability,

437.89.text:
something like
a dollar a month,

439.83.text:
which, at the time was,
of course, outlandish.

442.50.text:
Well, the physician
who performed the evaluation

444.50.text:
was very specific;
he defined the problem:

446.83.text:
gunshot wound, right thigh;
and rheumatism.

448.92.text:
All of the vital signs were
recorded with great detail.

452.00.text:
And, within the record,
he describes specifically

455.66.text:
the small superficial scars
in the midthigh

458.40.text:
and describes exactly
the date that it occurred

461.00.text:
and he also describes other
key comorbid conditions,

463.86.text:
like the fact that the patient
had an amputation

466.26.text:
of the middle finger through the
proximal interphalangeal joint,

470.17.text: so a great deal of detail.

472.10.text:
Obviously, not
an electronic health record,

474.46.text:
but we've always had
documentation and,

476.53.text:
to some degree,
as we've looked forward,

479.63.text:
it's been better
than we have today.

481.83.text:
So if we look at some
of the documentation

483.66.text:
we have today,
it's pretty bad.

485.46.text:
Now, hopefully, most clinicians
are not documenting like this,

489.30.text:
but it's still happening today
and we're still seeing

493.89.text:
and probably including
the physician who wrote them,

496.03.text:
and, really, this is
not only bad documentation;

499.07.text:
ultimately, we can't take
proper care of the patient,

501.73.text:
if we don't have good
documentation

503.63.text:
of the key parameters
of that patient

507.63.text:
Where does it all start?
Well, it starts where

510.13.text:
we were taught, in medical
school and residency,

512.86.text:
where we were taught to do
an external record review,

515.96.text:
to get a history
from the patient,

519.69.text:
to look at internal records,
to look at studies,

522.86.text:
and to pull all
of that information together

524.56.text:
in a very specific way
and make sure we understood

527.30.text:
all the key parameters
of the patient condition,

529.43.text:
so that we could come up
with the appropriate treatment.

533.17.text:
What are those types
of things we did?

534.56.text:
It's the same things we were
taught in medical school.

536.59.text:
What type of condition is it?
How do we categorize it?

539.63.text:
Is it type 1 diabetes,
type 2 diabetes?

542.20.text:
What was the onset? Was it
a month ago, was it 4 weeks ago?

548.10.text:
Was it caused
by an infectious agent?

550.33.text:
Was there some type
of internal failure?

556.83.text:
Is it one of those
subtrochanteric fractures?

561.59.text:
Is it an injury of the
upper pole of the kidney?

564.07.text:
Is it a problem with the left
upper lobe of the lung?

567.76.text:
Is it the right side,
the left side?

570.00.text:
Is it mild,
moderate, or severe?

571.92.text:
What are the environmental
factors around that?

574.89.text:
All of these things, again,
are key clinical concepts

578.10.text:
that are important, in terms
of taking care of the patient,

580.79.text:
and all of them are
the key parameters

582.83.text:
that we were taught,
in medical school and residency,

584.76.text:
that we should capture,
where relevant,

591.17.text:
is it paroxysmal,
is it recurring,

594.30.text:
is it acute or chronic?
Are there comorbid conditions?

597.56.text:
If that patient has diabetes,
did they have retinopathy,

600.46.text:
did they have
a neuropathic joint?

603.36.text:
If a patient has a spine
injury or a head injury,

605.56.text:
do they have loss of
consciousness or paralysis?

612.17.text:
Are we having normal healing?
Is it delayed?

615.66.text:
Is there a nonunion?
The fracture

617.53.text:
simply didn't heal at all;
or did it heal,

619.13.text:
pointed in the wrong direction,
and result in a malunion?

628.36.text: What was the cause of this?

629.89.text:
Was that patient involved
in a motor vehicle accident?

632.23.text:
How does that factor into how we
handle that patient's condition?

636.10.text:
How does it factor
into how that patient's

638.20.text:
claim and payment
is going to be handled?

639.83.text:
There's a lot of important
factors around that.

641.83.text:
And what type
of encounter was it:

643.33.text:
was it an initial encounter,
subsequent encounter?

645.56.text:
So we see that there's a lot
of key different parameters.

649.56.text:
So let's take one condition,
otitis media,

651.20.text:
a very common condition,
seen frequently

653.59.text:
in the pediatrician
and the family practice office.

657.00.text:
Now, we could look at that
patient who comes in,

658.92.text:
and the mother says the patient
just has an earache,

660.86.text:
and we could come up
with a diagnosis

662.66.text:
that simply says
what the mother said:

664.56.text:
otalgia, which basically
is just earache.

668.33.text:
Now, we really should be able
to do a bit better than that.

671.59.text:
So if the patient comes in,
we want to be able to capture,

674.10.text:
for that patient
who has otitis media,

677.20.text: what type of otitis it is.

678.73.text:
Is it just
a run-of-the-mill type;

680.69.text:
is it a specific type
of otitis media?

684.30.text:
What was the onset?
Is this acute?

687.92.text:
Did the patient have measles
or influenza or allergies

690.76.text:
that may have triggered
or caused this otitis?

693.20.text:
Which side was involved:
was it the right side,

699.79.text:
Was there a smoking history
in the family or the home

702.89.text:
and the patient comes in
recurrently with otitis media

706.43.text:
and is exposed to environmental
tobacco on a regular basis?

710.07.text:
Probably pretty important
stuff to know.

714.63.text: Is it acute, is it chronic?

717.20.text:
Did the patient have a rupture
of the membrane, or not?

720.73.text:
I can't imagine a patient
coming in with severe otitis

723.83.text:
and complaining of earache,
where the physician would not

726.00.text:
at least look in the ear to see
whether the membrane was intact;

729.20.text:
that's sort of one of the basic
things that we were taught.

732.07.text:
Or is there a drainage
that's serous or fluidlike

735.46.text:
or is it suppurative
or a purulent type of drainage?

738.79.text:
All of these things
are key factors and,

740.56.text:
if we look at ICD-10,
what we see is that a lot

743.86.text:
of these types of concepts
are captured in the code.

746.66.text:
We can now capture whether
there is a specific cause,

751.79.text:
whether there was
rupture of the membrane,

754.53.text:
whether there is drainage
of a serous type

759.03.text:
Much better to capture
this type of information

761.76.text:
to characterize the nature
of the condition,

763.63.text:
than simply say
the patient had an earache.

765.73.text:
Now, clearly, there's
a code for earache,

767.59.text:
but it should probably not be
the standard code we use

770.33.text:
and it should not be based
on the fact that we didn't

772.33.text:
document anything other than
the patient had an earache.

777.63.text:
there's still a lot of interest,
in terms of coding specificity.

781.50.text:
We've looked,
historically, at the data

782.92.text:
and the data shows that
we really have not captured

785.36.text:
a lot of information
about the patient

789.63.text:
and there's a lot
of pressure, looking at

790.96.text:
"maybe we should just not accept
these unspecified codes."

794.56.text:
Well, there's a real challenge
in that because there's times

796.69.text:
when unspecified codes are
exactly the right code to use.

800.86.text:
So how do we describe
poorly specified coding?

803.53.text:
So I'm going to propose
a definition, that:

805.76.text:
"Coding that does not fully
define the important parameters

808.83.text:
of the patient condition
that could otherwise be defined

812.10.text:
given the information available
to the observer (the clinician)

815.76.text:
and the coder is probably
less than optimal coding."

822.36.text:
may be very unspecified
for a very good reason.

825.76.text:
Sometimes we'll see
the patient early

827.30.text:
in the course
of the treatment.

828.79.text:
They present in; they said,
"Doc, I have abdominal pain.

831.73.text:
I don't know why it's there"
and you examine the patient;

835.10.text:
there's nothing specific
that you can identify.

837.66.text:
The patient cannot relate
what caused this

840.43.text:
or when it came on
and is very, very vague.

843.26.text: And we see this all the time.

844.63.text:
The proper code to use might be
"abdominal pain, unspecified".

849.03.text:
We have to ask, though,
if this is the 10th visit

851.26.text:
for the patient
and the diagnosis is still

854.07.text:
abdominal pain, unspecified,
we have to wonder

856.10.text:
whether we're adding sufficient
value at that point in time.

859.50.text:
So coding specificity
is something that may start out

862.50.text:
very nonspecific, because that's
all the information we have,

866.30.text:
but, assuming we evaluate that
patient and examine that patient

870.43.text:
and come up with
a more definitive diagnosis,

872.89.text:
ultimately, we should have
that more definitive diagnosis

878.10.text:
to get to that
better diagnosis.

884.00.text:
that there are a lot of codes
that are unspecified.

886.96.text:
We can essentially be
just as vague, in ICD-10,

891.96.text:
There are a lot of codes there
that are not terribly specific

895.76.text:
and a lot of codes that we
should rarely, if ever, use.

898.53.text:
For example, in ICD-10,
we frequently will have

904.73.text:
and we also have codes
that say "unspecified side".

908.23.text:
Now, we should rarely
use that;

909.63.text:
we should almost always know
our right from our left,

912.17.text:
particularly if we're
treating our patient.

913.50.text:
How can we possibly take care
of that patient, if we don't?

917.30.text:
We ought to know what
anatomical location it is.

920.66.text:
If we say "injury, limb",
it's pretty vague.

923.33.text:
Even the patient knows where
that was injured, in the limb,

926.86.text:
or what type of injury it was,
so that type of coding,

930.00.text:
at that level, should
probably never be considered,

932.73.text:
because there really isn't
a reason for it.

934.86.text:
Or, if you're an OB physician
treating a patient,

937.43.text:
you probably know
what trimester it is.

939.36.text:
It would be very, very rare,
if at all,

941.83.text:
that you would treat
a patient and say

945.86.text:
If you're treating
a patient with diabetes,

947.59.text:
you should probably know
what type of diabetes it is.

949.96.text:
If the patient has specific
known complications

952.63.text:
or comorbidities, that
should clearly be documented

955.43.text:
and, if relevant,
should be coded.

958.53.text:
We also should be able
to say

960.07.text:
is it severe, is it acute,
is it chronic.

963.03.text:
You probably
should not say things like

967.92.text:
because we never had
an unspecified code in ICD-9

971.33.text:
and we do in ICD-10,
and because how can we

973.79.text:
treat the patient
with respiratory failure,

976.17.text:
if we don't know whether
it's acute or chronic?

978.23.text:
So when we start looking
at some of these codes,

982.50.text:
makes a lot of sense;
as a matter of fact,

984.63.text:
we shouldn't be
making up stuff.

986.26.text:
If we don't know
what's going on,

987.76.text:
we should use
the more unspecified code,

990.26.text:
but there are many times when we
use an unspecified or vague code

994.26.text:
that really doesn't make
any sense

995.69.text:
and should rarely,
if ever, be used.

997.66.text:
Anytime we have care
that demands

999.76.text:
a more specific level
of detail,

1001.73.text:
in order to care
for the patient,

1003.30.text:
we should have the
documentation to support it.

1005.89.text:
If we're
at a specialty level,

1008.07.text:
we should be able
to provide more detail.

1010.53.text:
The primary care physician
may not know

1020.89.text:
So we have different levels
of specificity for good reasons:

1024.17.text:
Because it may be early
in the course of treatment;

1027.03.text:
it may be that a physician
or some other provider

1029.46.text:
who is at a different level,
who really doesn't know

1031.59.text:
all of the details,
at any point in time,

1034.13.text:
or may not have the training
to recognize more detail.

1037.20.text:
And then, we have coding
at a more specific detail level,

1039.96.text:
which is important
for patient care,

1042.26.text:
but may be coded by
a different type of provider,

1044.92.text:
who actually has
more specialty training.

1047.07.text:
There's a wide range of
different levels of specificity;

1050.00.text:
we should always try
and use the best specificity

1052.66.text:
that's important
for the patient care.

1055.07.text:
Ultimately, what we want
to be able to get is

1057.63.text:
good patient data
because good patient data

1059.83.text:
is going to be the foundation
for improving healthcare:

1062.66.text:
for understanding what we're
doing with patient care,

1067.66.text:
and different complexities
and different severity

1070.20.text:
and different complications
and different outcomes

1072.69.text:
and why some outcomes
are different than others,

1074.92.text:
because the patient's condition
is more or less severe

1078.13.text:
or a different type
of condition.

1079.63.text:
All of these things
are critically important

1081.83.text:
as we're moving into an era
of value-based purchasing,

1089.79.text:
of taking on
the risk of population.

1091.86.text:
Understanding the level
of the key parameters

1094.40.text:
of the patient condition, their
complexity, their severity:

1098.43.text:
all of those things become
increasingly more important

1100.92.text:
from a financial,
from an analytic,

1106.96.text:
good patient care is all
about good data;

1110.36.text:
good data is all about
good patient care

1112.26.text:
and, if we want
good patient data,

1114.36.text:
then we have to have
3 basic things.

1117.07.text:
We have to have:
observations of all the facts

1123.79.text:
of all those
key medical concepts.

1125.53.text:
As we were taught
in medical school

1127.26.text:
and has been brought to
our attention many times since:

1130.46.text:
"if it's not documented,
it didn't happen."

1132.79.text:
As a matter of fact,
if it's not documented,

1135.69.text:
we are going to remember it
'til the next time.

1138.40.text:
Coding that includes
all these key medical concepts

1143.00.text:
Coding professionals and others
have gone through

1145.40.text:
a lot of training
to look at the documentation

1147.63.text:
and come up
with the proper code,

1149.79.text:
but if the documentation
isn't there,

1151.79.text:
they simply can't
come up with a code

1153.50.text:
to represent accurately what
that patient's condition is.

1157.83.text:
So if we look at coding,
I think one of the things

1160.20.text:
that becomes very apparent is
that we are looking at an era

1163.56.text:
where we're trying to get
a lot better documentation,

1167.33.text:
resulting
in a lot better coding,

1169.66.text:
resulting in a lot better data
for a whole variety of purposes.

1174.00.text:
Accurate coding is a requirement
for good patient care;

1179.36.text:
to improve the quality
of care, overall,

1182.20.text:
the effectiveness of care,
and ensuring patient safety;

1187.86.text:
of important clinical concepts
of the patient condition

1191.26.text:
is a requirement
for good patient care.

1193.76.text:
Requirements for documentation
to support ICD-10

1198.83.text:
to support good patient care
and improve healthcare data.

1202.46.text:
I think we're going through
an era where we're seeing

1204.40.text:
the specificity and detail
and relevance of coding

1213.17.text:
We see this
in other industries.

1215.56.text:
We would not allow
the level of specificity

1218.33.text:
to be the ultimate level
of vagueness

1220.46.text:
if we order a pair of shoes
or if we order dinner,

1223.33.text:
or we would not expect our pilot
to tell us we're flying

1226.73.text:
to an unspecified location and
landing at an unspecified time.

1231.10.text:
You know, we expect specificity
in almost every other industry

1234.86.text:
and it's that point in time
where we really need

1237.20.text:
to start looking at getting
better documentation,

1239.73.text:
better data, for better
patient care, moving forward.

1242.63.text:
Thank you for participating
in this presentation.

1244.79.text:
I hope you found
some value in this.

1246.63.text:
I wanted to point out
that there are

1249.40.text:
a lot of great resources
out there.

1251.46.text:
CMS has a site
that they've put up

1254.76.text:
that includes a lot
of different resources.

1257.43.text:
These resources allow us
to pull down codes,

1263.63.text:
to pull down guidelines, to
pull down a lot of information.

1267.13.text:
All of this information
is for free.

1270.73.text:
There is a website called
"Road to 10"

1273.20.text:
which is specifically designed
for small provider practices,

1276.53.text:
to give some guidance,
in terms of how

1278.17.text:
to go through this transition,
to identify key resources,

1281.23.text:
to point to a number
of different resources.

1284.50.text:
I think it's important
to understand this

1286.26.text:
and start looking
at this soon

1287.96.text:
because the time
is closing quickly

1290.20.text:
and it's important
to get that understanding

1292.50.text:
of how is this going to
impact your practice

1295.07.text:
and how are you going
to best position yourself

1297.76.text:
to get the most
out of this.
